article.title: Genomic characterization and radiation tolerance of Naganishia kalamii sp. nov. and Cystobasidium onofrii sp. nov. from Mars 2020 mission assembly facilities

sections.introduction: Many fungal species, including yeasts, have been isolated and characterized from different extreme environments, such as the Antarctic continent (rocks, soil brines), Arctic ice-sheet and sea-ice, deep sea, deserts, etc.
sections.methods: Steps for sample collection and isolation of yeasts at the Jet Propulsion Laboratory Spacecraft Assembly Facility (JPL-SAF) and the Kennedy Space Center Payload Hazardous and Servicing Facility (KSC-PHSF) cleanrooms were previously described
sections.results: Naganishia kalamii belongs to Basidiomycota, class Tremellomycetes, and order Filobasidiales
sections.discussion: Microorganisms associated with NASA spacecraft assembly cleanrooms might hitchhike on spacecraft surfaces, contaminate extraterrestrial environments, or compromise the life-detection missions

article.insights_summary: This study characterizes two novel yeast species, Naganishia kalamii and Cystobasidium onofrii, isolated from NASA spacecraft assembly cleanrooms. The study highlights the importance of precise techniques like MLSA and WGS for yeast identification and warns about the potential contamination of extraterrestrial environments by these UV-C resistant yeasts.
article.acknowledgments: The research was carried out at the Jet Propulsion Laboratory, California Institute of Technology, under a contract with the National Aeronautics and Space Administration
